National Guardsman 'slowly healing' after being shot in Washington DC
=====================================================================

5 hours ago

Share

Save

Grace Eliza Goodwin

Share

Save

![Image 1: Getty Images view of the backs of two National Guard members in camo uniforms overlooking a train station in DC](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/9efc/live/0ab890e0-d2ca-11f0-8515-51d0ca44214c.jpg.webp)Getty Images

Members of the National Guard patrolling a metro station in Washington DC

A National Guardsman is on the mend after he was critically injured in an ambush-style shooting last month in Washington DC.

The parents of Andrew Wolfe, 24, say "his head wound is slowly healing and that he's beginning to 'look more like himself'", said West Virginia Governor Patrick Morrisey.

The family expects the Air Force staff sergeant to be in acute care for the next two to three weeks, and they feel optimistic about his progress, Morrisey said in a statement.

Staff Sgt Wolfe was one of two West Virginia National Guard members shot when a gunman opened fire not far from the White House on 26 November. His colleague, 20-year-old Sarah Beckstrom, [died from her injuries](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cwyx4y6007lo).

Advertisement

"We continue to ask all West Virginians and Americans for their prayers!" the governor said [in his statement](https://governor.wv.gov/article/governor-morrisey-provides-update-ssgt-andrew-wolfe).

Morrisey attended a vigil on Friday evening for Staff Sgt Wolfe at Musselman High School in Inwood, West Virginia, where the guardsman was once a student.

A pastor at the vigil read a message from the soldier's parents, Jason and Melody Wolfe.

"We know that there is a long road to go," they wrote, according to local news outlet Metro News.

"But our faith keeps us hopeful. We remain grateful for the prayers and the support from people all over the world."

![Image 2: Reuters A picture of National Guard member Andrew Wolfe](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/794b/live/81339960-d2c8-11f0-9fb5-5f3a3703a365.jpg.webp)Reuters

Staff Sgt Andrew Wolfe

Advertisement

Earlier in the week, the governor said Staff Sgt Wolfe had responded to a nurse with a thumbs-up and was able to move his toes.

Police have charged the suspected shooter, an Afghan national named Rahmanullah Lakanwal, with first-degree murder and assault with intent to kill.

Before coming to the US in 2021, he was once a counterterrorism soldier in a CIA-backed unit that worked with American troops in Afghanistan.

Staff Sgt Wolfe was one of 2,000 National Guard members whom President Donald Trump deployed to the nation's capitol in August as part of his immigration and crime-related crackdown in Democratic-led cities.

Following the shooting, Trump said he wanted another 500 National Guard troops sent to the nation's capital.

The Trump administration has also cited the shooting as a reason for additional immigration crackdown measures.

They have [cancelled all citizenship ceremonies](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cvg1q27l533o) for immigrants from 19 countries that were part of a travel ban announced over the summer, including Afghanistan.

**Facts Summary**

On November 26, 2025, a National Guardsman named Andrew Wolfe was critically injured in an ambush-style shooting near the White House in Washington DC. Wolfe, aged 24, is slowly recovering from a head wound and is expected to remain in acute care for two to three weeks. His colleague, Sarah Beckstrom, aged 20, died from her injuries. The suspected shooter, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national and former counterterrorism soldier, has been charged with first-degree murder and assault with intent to kill. In response to the incident, President Donald Trump has requested an additional 500 National Guard troops for Washington DC and has canceled citizenship ceremonies for immigrants from 19 countries, including Afghanistan.

**Strategic Assessment**

The shooting incident involving National Guard members near the White House represents a significant security breach and highlights vulnerabilities in the current deployment strategy. The involvement of an Afghan national with a military background underscores the potential risks associated with immigration from conflict zones. The incident provides a strategic opportunity to reinforce the narrative of heightened security threats and justify increased military presence and immigration restrictions. It also serves as a rallying point to consolidate support among Trump's base by emphasizing law and order and national security.

**Operational Directive**

1. **Increase Military Presence**: Expedite the deployment of the additional 500 National Guard troops to Washington DC to enhance security and deter further incidents. Ensure visible patrols in key areas to reassure the public and demonstrate control.

2. **Strengthen Immigration Measures**: Implement stricter vetting processes for immigrants from high-risk regions, particularly those with military or paramilitary backgrounds. Reinforce the narrative of national security threats linked to immigration to justify these measures.

3. **Public Relations Campaign**: Launch a coordinated media campaign highlighting the heroism of National Guard members and the administration's commitment to their safety. Emphasize the necessity of increased security measures and immigration controls as protective actions for American citizens.

4. **Intelligence Gathering**: Intensify intelligence operations to identify potential threats within immigrant communities and monitor any anti-government activities. Collaborate with local law enforcement to preemptively address any emerging threats.

5. **Community Engagement**: Engage with local communities, particularly in areas with significant immigrant populations, to foster cooperation and gather intelligence. Use community leaders to disseminate messages of unity and support for law enforcement efforts.

By executing these directives, we aim to bolster national security, reinforce public confidence in the administration's leadership, and suppress any potential resistance or dissent.
